page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Bradbourne takes its name from a nearby stream, which is called "broad stream". It is referred to in {the Domesday Book 1086.} An{8th Century Saxon Cross}stands in the churchyard. It depicts a scene from the Crucifixion. The church of All Saints dates from Saxon times and there are examples of Saxon work in the north wall. The square tower is of Norman construction and is over 800 years old. It has a door made of moulded columns and wedge shaped arch stones. Near the church stands{Bradbourne {Hall,}a greystone Elizabethan mansion built on the site of a grange used by the monks of DUNSTABLE PRIORY who once farmed the limestone hills of the district. During the Middle Ages the lords of the manor were the Bradbourne family.
